Award.AwardTitle: Metaplectic Whittaker functions and quantum groups
Award.AbstractNarration:
Whittaker functions are important in both number theory and physics. In number theory, they arise in the Fourier expansions of automorphic forms. In physics, they appeared in Kostant's work on the Toda lattice and in recent work of Gerasimov, Lebedev and Oblezin with connections to statistical and quantum physics and mirror symmetry.
Brubaker, Bump, Chinta, Friedberg and Gunnells have been investigating Whittaker functions on metaplectic groups.
They found that these have expressions as sums over Kashiwara crystals. Moreover they have expressions as partition functions of statistical physics, in which the Boltzmann weights are Gauss sums. This allows the Yang-Baxter equation to be introduced as a new tool in their study and opens up a new field of investigation.

The proposer has been working with Brubaker, Chinta, Friedberg and Gunnells over the last few years over a project which began in number theory but is developing connections with mathematical physics. The objects under study are "Dirichlet Series" that resemble the Riemann zeta function, which is fundamental in number theory. Their symmetries, known as "functional equations" resemble the symmetries of Lie groups. It has recently been found that they may be realized in terms of a class of models arising in statistical and quantum physics, which has opened up a new area of investigation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The inspirations for modern mathematics have come from different sources. Motivation has come from physics and the laws of nature. On the other hand, motivation has come from number theory and combinatorics. These sources seem unconnected, yet there are surprising connections.

The theory of automorphic forms blossomed spectacularly since the 1960's with motivation coming mainly from number theory. Yet automorphic forms also appear increasingly in mathematical physics. Connections between disparate areas of research are always important since one area may shed light on theother, out of which something genuinely new may come.

This project found a new connection between mathematical physics and number theory. The movtivating problem came from number theory, in an idea of Hoffstein to attack problems using metaplectic automorphic forms. Each instance of this method required solution of a difficult combinatorial problem, and produced an interesting function called a Weyl group multiple Dirichlet series. These are related to metaplectic Whittaker functions, whose study had been started in the 1980's by Kazhdan and Patterson.

Two groups of researchers came to focus on putting these combinatorial problems on a more systematic footing. On the one hand, Brubaker, Bump, Friedberg and Hoffstein found a new combinatorial formula for metaplectic Whittaker functions. On the other hand, Chinta and Gunnells found a different formula. The equivalence of the two was not obvious.

The formula found by Brubaker, Bump, Friedberg and Hoffstein gave the first clue of a connection with mathematical physics. One way of writing this formula involved Kashiwara crystals, combinatorial structures coming from quantum groups. This suggested a set of combinatorial tools, and difficult proofs for the needed results were given by Brubaker, Bump and Friedberg in their Annals of Mathematics Study, "Weyl Group Multiple Dirichlet Series: Type A Combinatorial Theory," which appeared in 2011 near the beginning of the grant. One key fact called "Statement B" gave the main properties of the multiple Dirichlet series. Its proof was fascinating but difficult.

A different way of writing the formula had the appeal of making the connection with mathematical physics stronger and held the promise of a different kind of proof of the needed properties. This reinterpreted the Whittaker function as the partition function of a solvable lattice model. The ideas of statistical physics thus come in directly in this approach, which was spelled out in a 2012 paper called "Metaplectic Ice" by Brubaker, Bump, Chinta, Friedberg and Gunnells. It seemed possible to bring in a different tool, the Yang-Baxter equation, a cornerstone of many investigations in mathematical physics.

Thus in 2012 we thus envisioned the use of the Yang-Baxter equation to study metaplectic Whittaker functions. It was not until recently that we were able to do this in the recent paper of Brubaker, Bump and Buciumas. (A new insight was needed.)  We show that the Whittaker functions on the metaplectic group of degree n may be studied using a Yang-Baxter equation of a type known as the Perk-Schultz equation. This is associated with a "supersymmetric" quantum group.

To explain what supersymmetric means in mathematical physics, particles in the universe are classified as fermions or bosons. In usual theories of symmetry called Lie algebras, fermions and bosons cannot be interchanged. A broader mathematical structure known as a Lie superalgebra is needed in order to explain symmetries that mix fermions and bosons together. The appearance of Lie superalgebras in this investigation of metaplectic Whittaker functions is an unexpected development.

As a result of this discovery, we may now relate the different approaches of Brubaker, Bump and Friedberg and of Chinta and Gunnells (explained above) more directly than before. A new proof of "Statement B" (explained above) is now possible. Finally, the scattering matrix of certain operators on the Whittaker functions, computed in the 1980's by Kazhdan and Patterson, is seen to coincide with an R-matrix that appears also in mathematical physics. This is a new connection between number theory and physics.

In this report I have chosen to highlight the piece of work which I consider the single most spectacular success of the grant. Other work includes several papers by Brubaker, Bump, Friedberg and Licata on relationships between representations of Hecke algebras, Iwahori Whittaker functions and unique functionals,  and work of Bump and Choie on Schubert Eisenstein series. The grant also supported the preparation of four books. One I have already mentioned; another, near completion, is a text by Bump and Anne Schilling on Crystal Bases that redoes the foundations of this important theory in a new way, giving purely combinatorial proofs of all the main facts, whereas other treatments have required powerful tools from other fields, whether it be quantum groups, the Littelmann path method, or geometric Langlands theory. By giving purely combinatorial proofs of combinatorial results, we hope that we have that we have written a unique and useful book.
